conclusion: Objects A and B move through the air and come into contact with objects C, D, E, and F due to gravity.

In the first labeled image, A is a flat surface/sheet on the left side, B is a flat surface/sheet on the right side, C is a yellow block, D is a red block, and E and F are green blocks of different heights.
In the other images, the same objects are visible without labels, and in the third image, the flat surfaces (A and B) are pinned up with colored pins.
Objects C, D, E, and F are blocks resting on a circular tray, and objects A and B appear to be flexible sheets or fabrics.
When objects A and B move through the air and are placed over objects C, D, E, and F, they will initially drape over these blocks.

Due to gravity, the sheets (A and B) will conform to the shape of the underlying blocks, create draped formations where they're not supported by blocks, and develop tension in areas where they're stretched between support points.

The sheets will make contact with the highest points of blocks C, D, E, and F first, and gravity will pull the sheets downward, causing them to conform to the blocks' shapes and create folds and depressions between the blocks.

As seen in the third image, the sheets are pinned up using colored pins, taking on the shape of the underlying topology created by the blocks, with valleys forming between blocks due to gravitational pull.

When objects A and B (flexible sheets) move through the air and are placed over objects C, D, E, and F (blocks), gravity will cause the sheets to drape over and conform to the shapes of the blocks, making direct contact at their highest points and forming draped curves and folds in between.
